data.title: Implement GraphicsDevice.Reset Methods
data.body:
We need to fully implement the 3 different `GraphicsDevice.Reset()` methods as defined by XNA:

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.graphicsdevice.reset.aspx

These are important to PC builds where devices can be lost over driver and hardware issues.

data.title: Fixes OpenAL buffers and sources management
data.body:
While investigating #4413, I have noticed that OpenAL buffers were wrongly managed: every `SoundEffectInstance.Play()` a new buffer is created without freeing the previous one from the OpenAL context, and buffers are bound to one source at a time (buffer-source relationship is forced to be 1-1, instead of 1-multiple).

There is two problems with this: buffers are not reused, and they are not freed, which is causing #4413 to happen (the buffer limit is reached, and the number of 16 I mentioned is obviously wrong and was pure coincidence).

This PR does the following:
- attaching a buffer to `SoundEffect` instead of `SoundEffectInstance` so they can be reused and don't depend on one single source (works like XAudio2)
- removing source attachment from `OALSoundBuffer` so they are independent and only bound to a playing `SoundEffectInstance`
- correctly disposing the buffers upon `SoundEffect.Dispose()`

Fixes #4413
Fixes #4411
Fixes #4403 

While reviewing this PR, #4407 & #4410 should help getting rid of the remaining MacOS problems. (I'll most probably have to rebase them -- @tomspilman would you prefer that I push all these OpenAL changes in this present PR ?)

We've tested that extensively and it seems to work just fine. No leaks or runtime allocations to declare.
Some good testing from other developers would be welcome (inc. on mobile). @dellis1972 @cra0zy @endimilojkoski

UPDATE:

I have updated this PR to make `OggStream` use the `OpenALSoundController` source pool. This will make sure that there is no conflict between `Song` and `SoundEffectInstance`. The source limit will now correctly be respected and the correct exception will be thrown if need be. This makes `OpenALSoundController` to be the one and only place where OpenAL sources are managed.

data.title: GraphicsDeviceManager partial class refactor

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This PR is an attempt to clean and split up GraphicsDeviceManager to allow for partial class extension on new platforms.
- Copied existing `GraphicsDeviceManager` to `GraphicsDeviceManager.Legacy.cs` to maintain behavior of old platforms.
- New version of `GraphicsDeviceManager.cs` without any platform specific code in it.
- The Windows, Windows8, Windows Phone, Windows Phone 8.1, Windows Universal, and Web platforms now use the new `GraphicsDeviceManager`.
- Added some more reference docs.
- Minor cleanups in Windows platform files.

Fixes #2859 
Fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1762.

Once we switch over the OpenTK backed to support this then also https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1748 should be fixed if it isn't already.

data.title: Pipeline tool lists content processors twice

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I have a .mgcb project that references DLLs with custom content processors. When I load the project in the Pipeline tool the first time, I see one entry for each of my custom processors. When I reload the mgcb project (without closing the Pipeline tool), the custom processors are listed twice:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3626369/12325630/cf414ed8-bacb-11e5-82bb-972723663353.png)

I have found the following cause: [PipelineType.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Common/PipelineTypes.cs) collects the list of processors in [ResolveAssemblies()](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Common/PipelineTypes.cs#L398-L438). It first collects all processors of the assemblies which are currently loaded in the AppDomain. Then it collect all processors from the custom content pipeline DLLs referenced in the .mgcb.
This works the first time, but when the project is reloaded, the custom content pipeline DLLs are already loaded in the AppDomain and ResolveAssemblies() will find the same processors in both loops and add them twice.

In my projects this is only a bit irritating but no real problem. But could this be a problem if a user tests several .mgcb projects that use different versions of a custom content processor DLL?

A quick fix would be to just ignore duplicate entries. Ideally, we want to unload custom content processor DLLs before loading the next project. However, I think it is currently not possible in .NET to unload DLLs. I think we can only unload whole AppDomains.

data.title: Moved Stock Effect Resources
data.body: This PR moves the resource loading for the stock effects to a partial class that can be overloaded for new platforms.

data.title: Moved Stock Effect Resources
data.body: This PR moves the resource loading for the stock effects to a partial class that can be overloaded for new platforms.

data.title: SpriteBatch performance optimisation
data.body:
This is an optimisation for the common case of drawing sprites without any rotation.

I benchmarked my optimised `SpriteBatchItem.Set` method against the normal version and found it to be roughly 3 times faster.

My top-down 2D game uses a mix of unrotated sprites (e.g. tiles) and rotated sprites (e.g. characters and objects), and this optimisation gives it a fairly respectable frame rate increase (around 10%).

Obviously your results may vary though depending on the number of sprites being drawn and how many of those are rotated. But I believe this should be a worthwhile optimisation in general for most users.

data.title: Add ProcessorParam Preprocessor Support
data.body:
This might be extremely handy when targeting multiple GPU chip sets on android. 
Because android supports a ton of compression formats the chances are multiple .apk's would be required. Rather than having multiple .mgcb files it would be nice to be able to do

/processorParam:TextureFormat=$(TextureFormat)

and then provide that either via the command line

/define:Textureformat=Compressed

or (more likely) via the following in the .mcgb file itself and pass the /config parameter.

$if config=PVRTC
$set TextureFormat=PVRCompressed
$endif

Then replace the $(TextureFormat) of the ProcessorParam when its parsed.
At the moment the following is required for each which can be a bit of a pain when dealing with multiple compression types.

$if config=PVRTC
/processorParam:TextureFormat=PVRCompressed
$endif
$if config=ATI
/processorParam:TextureFormat=ATICompressed
$endif

Comments?

data.title: AudioEngine: FileNotFoundException HResult -2147024894 Universal Windows App
GL VertexElementFormat.Short4 Bug?
data.body:
I happened to find this...

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/GraphicsExtensions.cs#L70

Which looks like a bug...  shouldn't that be 4?  @dellis1972 @KonajuGames ?

data.title: VertexElementFormat.Short4 and .Color
data.body:
`VertexElementFormat.Short4` and `VertexElementFormat.Color` doesn't pass through to shader correctly. Instead, they screw up the vertex input structure entirely, causing other members of the structure also become fancy.

These formats must be replaced by `Vector4` (when porting from XNA) to work correctly. At least for `Color`, the vertex declaration can be left defined as is, just the actual vertex buffer data must be passed as `Vector4`. For `Short4` such a test cannot be done, since that also differs in bit-representation from `Vector4`.

Platform is DirectX Windows.

data.title: [OpenAL] Buffer limit ? OS X crash at 16
data.body:
In #4403 we discussed about the maximum number of playing sources. It is stated that OS X has a limit of 256 sources and 1024 buffers.

However, I'm getting a lot of AL errors on this line: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Audio/OALSoundBuffer.cs#L34

When debugging, there are 16 pooled `SoundEffectInstance` in the `SoundEffetInstancePool` and 0 playing instances.

This makes me question the 1024 buffers and 256 sources limits.

What is strange, is that the current source limit of 32 seems fine (`OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES`). I already played up to 32 sources simultaneously. But the buffer limit looks to be 16... Could this be possible?

I also noticed that while being pooled, `SoundEffectInstance` retain their `OALSoundBuffer` and create a new `OALSoundBuffer` when removed from the pool without clearing / reusing the previous one. Could this be the cause? But the number of 16 buffers still seem pretty low.

@cra0zy @dellis1972 Any idea?

data.title: [OpenTK] Leaks when closing application
data.body:
`Game.Exit()` results in the following console output (debug):

```
XInputJoystick leaked, did you forget to call Dispose()?
NativeWindowBase leaked, did you forget to call Dispose()?
[Warning] INativeWindow leaked (OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WinGLNative). Did you forget to call INativeWindow.Dispose()?
[Warning] Resource leaked: OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WinRawInput.
[Warning] Failed to release device context 184620535. Windows error: 0.
NativeWindowBase leaked, did you forget to call Dispose()?
[Warning] INativeWindow leaked (OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WinGLNative). Did you forget to call INativeWindow.Dispose()?
[Warning] {0} leaked, did you forget to call Dispose()?
[OpenTK] OpenTK.Platform.Factory+UnsupportedPlatform leaked with 0 live resources, did you forget to call Dispose()?
[OpenTK] OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WinFactory leaked with 5 live resources, did you forget to call Dispose()?
OpenTK.Platform.Factory leaked, did you forget to call Dispose()?
```

Seeing joystick driver leaking makes me think of an issue described in #4252: on MacOS, after closing an application, GamePads don't work anymore unless they are unplugged & re-plugged.

P.S.: this is the Windows output, I'm not seeing on MacOS. :grey_question:

data.title: [OpenAL] Song playback crashes after a while
data.body:
After about 20 minutes of playing different `Song`, we end up having this error:

```
System.InvalidOperationException: Invalid Name
at MonoGame.Utilities.ALHelper.Check () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0
at MonoGame.Utilities.OggStreamer.EnsureBuffersFilled () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0
at System.Threading.Thread.StartInternal () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0
```

I don't know yet on which AL call it failed, and this can be related to MacOS only.

May be related to #4413

data.title: Fixes OpenAL crashing upon exiting on MacOS
data.body:
This fixes an exit error discussed in #4153 where `Alc.DestroyContext()` could be called twice and raise an error on MacOS.

@dellis1972 You may be interested in testing this.

data.title: Oculus Rift Template
data.body:
We should consider adding template with out of the box Oculus Rift support.

We can use this 2013 article as a starting point for implementing support:

  https://visualstudiomagazine.com/articles/2013/10/30/virtual-reality--in-dotnet-part-1.aspx
  https://visualstudiomagazine.com/articles/2013/12/02/building-a-virtual-reality-game-part-2.aspx

Doesn't need to be very complex... just a spinning cube...  but should show we support it.

Likely this template should be implemented against the new project creation tool in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/4295.

data.title: Crashes on iOS 9 - OpenALSoundController
data.body:
Hi,

my app crashes on iOS 9 devices.
It worked for me after removing a line of code in OpenALSoundController.cs.

```
    private bool OpenSoundController()
    {
```
# if MONOMAC || IOS

```
        //alcMacOSXMixerOutputRate(PREFERRED_MIX_RATE);
```
# endif

...

Regards
Ronny

data.title: Tidying OpenAL constants
data.body:
Fixes #4403

`SoundEffectInstancePool` unused constants have been removed, and `SoundEffect` constants are now based upon `OpenALSoundController` constants (minus 1, because NVorbis uses a sound source and this should be subtracted).

The maximum of playing instances for DesktopGL has been set to 256, beause MacOS & Linux share this limit (even though Windows doesn't have a limit).

data.title: Add stream-based content import
data.body:
This adds a stream-based content importing API.  As per #4342, our asset importing system is primarily stream based, because we might be sourcing content from non-file based streams (like over the network).  Right now whenever we import content we have to take the stream (which might already be loaded from a file), write it out to disk somewhere, pass that filename into MonoGame (which might then read a stream again) to perform the content import.

By providing a stream-based content importing API, it removes the requirement to have a temporary file on-disk, and makes importing assets from in-memory or network sources easier.

data.title: Fixed DesktopGL on MacOS
data.body:
Fullscreen Toggling was not working on DesktopGL at all. 
StorageDevice on DesktopGL was not working on MacOS.

Both tested on MacOS :)

data.title: Gtk Pipeline, Use Common Filter Output Code and minor bugfix
data.body:
Stuff done:
- Use common code for Gtk Pipline output filtering from #4272
  - Fix Clean / Skip Regex
- Disable loading setting from file for Gtk Pipeline on menu update... no point, they are already in memory

data.title: OpenAL and maximum playing instances
data.body:
Hello,

It looks like the maximum of playing instances on all OpenAL platforms is set to 32 (`OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES`).

However, this limit is not considered in `SoundEffect` which has its own `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES` set to `int.MaxValue` (DesktopGL) or `256` (XamMac).

There is yet another constant in `SoundEffectInstancePool.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES`, but this one is never used. The `SoundEffectInstancePool` size is `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES`.

Fix proposal:
- set `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES` to `OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES` on all OpenAL platforms and cleaning the duplicated / unused values;

P.S.: unless explicitly documented, it is advised to set `OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES` to 32 (most modern hardware do 64, but for compatibility it is safer to stick to 32, and there is no way to query this limit by code).

P.S. 2: `MediaPlayer` uses 1 unchecked source too, which means that the limit of 32 is wrong if the real hardware limit is 32 too.

data.title: Screen scaled up on low-end Windows Phone 8.1 devices
data.body: On some devices (f.e. Lumia 630) touch positions are scaled up for Y component (portrait) when software button bar is visible.

data.title: [Win Pipeline] Toolbar and saving settings
data.body:
